title: Vertical Hydroponics Farm — Sustainable Urban Agriculture

envelopes.name: Crop Growth Optimization
assumptions: Growth models trained on 18 months of crop cycle data across lettuce, herbs, and microgreens.
Yield predictions account for variety genetics, growth stage, and environmental conditions.
Harvest timing optimizes both nutritional value and market demand.
constraints: Never harvest below 95% optimal maturity without quality override
Growth cycles must maintain 30% buffer capacity for demand spikes
Crop rotation schedules respect nutrient recovery periods

envelopes.name: Environmental Control Systems
assumptions: Climate models maintain temperature (65-75°F), humidity (60-70%), CO2 (800-1200 ppm), and lighting (12-18 hr photoperiod).
LED spectrum optimization balances energy efficiency with photosynthesis.
HVAC systems respond to external weather and internal load changes.
constraints: Temperature variance cannot exceed ±3°F without alert escalation
Humidity spikes above 75% trigger mold prevention protocols
CO2 levels below 600 ppm require immediate ventilation adjustment

envelopes.name: Water & Nutrient Management
assumptions: Nutrient solution models balance N-P-K ratios, pH (5.5-6.5), and EC (1.2-2.4 mS/cm) by crop type.
Water recirculation achieves 95% reuse efficiency with minimal waste.
Automated dosing systems adjust based on sensor feedback and plant uptake.
constraints: pH drift beyond 5.0-7.0 range requires immediate correction
EC imbalance >0.3 mS/cm from target triggers nutrient adjustment
Water contamination detected must halt irrigation and initiate purge

envelopes.name: Harvest & Quality Assurance
assumptions: Quality models assess visual appearance, nutrient density, shelf life, and pathogen risk.
Harvest windows optimize freshness for 24-48 hour delivery cycles.
Post-harvest handling maintains cold chain integrity.
constraints: Never ship produce testing positive for E. coli or Salmonella
Shelf life projections must guarantee 7+ days post-delivery
Visual defects exceeding 5% trigger batch quality review

envelopes.name: Energy & Sustainability
assumptions: Energy models optimize HVAC, lighting, and pumps for cost and carbon footprint.
Solar panels and battery storage offset 40% of grid consumption.
Demand response programs shift loads to off-peak hours.
constraints: Peak energy usage cannot exceed 85% of contracted capacity
Carbon intensity targets: <0.3 kg CO2e per kg produce
Renewable energy percentage must stay above 35%

envelopes.name: Food Safety & Compliance
assumptions: Compliance models track USDA GAP, FSMA, and organic certification requirements.
Traceability systems log every batch from seed to sale.
Audit readiness maintained with continuous monitoring and documentation.
constraints: Any food safety violation requires immediate corrective action and reporting
Traceability gaps exceeding 30 minutes trigger investigation
Certification expiration within 60 days requires renewal initiation

agents.name: YieldPredictor
agents.role: crop yield forecasting and harvest scheduling

agents.name: QualityInspector
agents.role: visual defect and nutrient density analysis

agents.name: LoadOptimizer
agents.role: energy consumption scheduling and demand response

agents.name: SafetyReporter
agents.role: food safety incident reporting and corrective actions

events.label: Envelope promoted
events.detail: Crop growth envelope (REV-VH-001-B) activated with updated yield models for spring growing season.

events.label: Envelope promoted
events.detail: Environmental control envelope (REV-VH-002-C) activated with refined HVAC algorithms for energy efficiency.

events.label: Harvest schedule optimized
events.detail: YieldPredictor scheduled lettuce harvest for zones 3-7 at hour 96. Projected yield: 2,400 lbs. Maturity: 97%. Optimal market window aligned.

events.label: LED spectrum adjusted
events.detail: LightingOptimizer shifted blue spectrum +15% for leafy greens in zones 1-4. Photosynthesis efficiency projected +8%. Energy cost neutral.

events.label: Envelope promoted
events.detail: Harvest and quality assurance envelope activated for spring harvest cycle.

events.label: Temperature variance exceeded
events.detail: ClimateController detected zone 5 temperature: 79.2°F (target: 72°F, threshold: 75°F). HVAC compressor lag suspected. Escalating to manual override.

events.label: Emergency cooling activated
events.detail: Environment Steward approved backup chiller activation for zone 5. Temperature stabilized at 72.5°F within 40 minutes. Primary HVAC scheduled for maintenance.

events.label: Envelope promoted
events.detail: Food safety and compliance envelope activated for quarterly audit preparation.

events.label: Nutrient solution adjusted
events.detail: NutrientBalancer increased potassium +12% for basil zones. EC adjusted to 2.1 mS/cm. pH stable at 6.2. Predicted growth acceleration: 4 days to harvest.

events.label: pH drift detected
events.detail: pHController flagged zone 8 water pH: 4.7 (target: 6.0, critical: <5.0). Root damage risk imminent. Irrigation halted. Buffer dosing initiated.

events.label: Reservoir purge required
events.detail: Nutrition Steward ordered zone 8 reservoir drain and refill. pH restored to 6.1 after 2 hours. Root inspection scheduled. 80 plants quarantined.

events.label: Pest treatment recommended
events.detail: CropHealthMonitor detected aphid presence in zone 2 (12 plants affected). Recommends beneficial insect release (ladybugs). Organic certification compliant.

events.label: Harvest initiated
events.detail: MaturityAssessor confirmed lettuce zones 3-7 ready: 98% maturity, nutrient density optimal. Harvest crew dispatched. Projected pack time: 6 hours.

events.label: Visual defects flagged
events.detail: QualityInspector detected 7.2% tip burn in zone 6 lettuce (threshold: 5%). Suspected calcium deficiency. Recommends nutrient adjustment for next cycle.

events.label: Calcium supplementation added
events.detail: Nutrition Steward revised nutrient protocol: +20% calcium for lettuce varieties. Target EC: 1.8 mS/cm. Prevents tip burn observed in recent harvest.
events.reason: Field data shows calcium deficiency correlation with tip burn in lettuce crops.

events.label: Demand response activated
events.detail: LoadOptimizer shifted HVAC and pumps to off-peak schedule (10pm-6am). Energy cost reduction: 18%. Solar + battery covering 62% of daytime load.

events.label: Carbon intensity exceeded
events.detail: CarbonTracker reported weekly carbon footprint: 0.34 kg CO2e/kg produce (target: <0.30). Grid electricity 72% during cloudy week. Recommends battery expansion.

events.label: DSG: Weekly yield review
events.detail: Growth Stewardship Group reviewed 7-day cycle. Yield accuracy: 96%. Identified microgreens underperforming by 8%. Root cause: lighting spectrum mismatch.

events.label: Microgreens lighting updated
events.detail: Environment Steward adjusted LED spectrum for microgreens: +25% red, +10% far-red. Photoperiod extended to 16 hours. Projected growth rate +12%.
events.reason: DSG findings show microgreens require higher red spectrum for optimal growth.

events.label: Audit readiness confirmed
events.detail: TraceabilityLogger reports 100% batch documentation for 8-day period. Zero traceability gaps. Food safety protocols: compliant. Organic certification: active.

events.label: Shelf life validation passed
events.detail: QualityInspector confirmed harvest batch H-1247: 9.2 days projected shelf life. Nutrient retention: 94% at day 7. Cold chain maintained. Approved for distribution.

events.label: Certification renewal due
events.detail: CertificationMonitor flagged USDA Organic certification expires in 45 days. Requires renewal documentation and inspector visit scheduling.

events.label: Renewal process initiated
events.detail: Compliance Steward submitted renewal application to USDA. Inspector visit scheduled for day 35. All documentation current. Zero non-conformances expected.

events.label: 10-day production summary
events.detail: Total yield: 6,800 lbs across 4 varieties. Waste: 3.2% (target: <5%). Average maturity: 97%. Market fulfillment: 100%. Revenue: $34,200.
